awd_titl_txt: Workshop: Biology, Information, Communication and Coding Theory [BITCC]
awd_abstract_narration:
Nontechnical Description
The goal of the proposed workshop is to provide an opportunity for an interdisciplinary and diverse ensemble of experts from disparate areas of biology, physics, computer science, math, telecommunications, and philosophy to discuss advances and next steps in understanding life and its fundamental processes through the Information, Communication, and Coding Theory (ICCT) framework. Approaching the study of living systems from a fundamental ICCT perspective provides a unifying reference for comparatively exploring biological phenomena across multiple scales, and provides a basis for design and engineering synthetic biological systems.  In addition to soliciting participation from a diverse group of women and underrepresented investigators in the biological and mathematical sciences, part of the broader impact of this timely workshop includes the public dissemination of workshop outcomes through a participant drafted publication. 


Technical Description
Organized by investigators established in the field of biological information and communication theory, the workshop will explore ICCT paradigms within and across traditional scales of the biological sciences.   A diverse group of U.S. scientist, with representative participation from the international community, will assemble to address progress, challenges, and opportunities at the intersection of biology and ICCT.  The workshop will consist of multiple sessions with driver key note seminars showcasing cutting-edge research and highlighting advances in the use of the ICCT framework in biology and engineering, and breakout sessions and panel discussions to identify challenges in the field.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Information, communication and coding theory (ICCT) define a theoretical framework with the potential to unify our understanding of biology across multiple scales of organization. The Biology through Information, communication and coding theory (BIOTICC) workshop, held in Alexandria, Virginia on January 21-22, 2020, convened a group of 66 experts from academia, industry and government to discuss current advances in the use of ICCT in biology, identify current and future challenges for the development of a unified ICCT framework in biology and establish a well-defined roadmap for coordinating and advancing research and technology development in the establishment of ICCT as a solid theoretical framework for biology. The workshop was open to the general public and promoted diversity by including speakers from underrepresented fields in science in engineering as well as participants across all career stages, providing competitive travel fellowships to facilitate their access and adopting a workshop structure, with small group breakouts, to foster their participation. The workshop identified several key elements that need to be addressed in order to enable the broad adoption of ICCT in biology, such as the need to define criteria to stipulate and quantify information transmission across biological organization levels, the development of the theoretical framework to adequately represent time dependencies and biological feedback processes and the need to leverage the underlying evolutionary process to enable the contextualization of biological information in a unified framework. Workshop participants concluded that encapsulation of biological systems into subsystems, and formally defining how to handle the information transmission among subsystems was a foundational aspiration for the field in its aim to generalize the applicability of the ICCT framework in biology. Participants noted that, in defining a universal framework, the ICCT paradigm also puts forward a transversal metric that can be used to formally compare and interrogate biological systems across spatial and temporal scales, and that this approach has therefore a transformational potential for furthering a common understanding of biology. Workshop discussions emphasized the need for the development and maintenance of publicly accessible resources for training and implementation of the ICCT framework in biology, including targeted short primers on the different foundational components of ICCT and on its applications in biology and ICCT modules adapted for core and advanced biology curricula courses, to foster awareness of the applicability of ICCT in biology among future generations of biologists and engineers.
